The Causes and Conditions of King Parantapa's Realization of Pratyekabuddhahood
Taking refuge in the Omniscient World-Honored One, who illuminates the three times,
Taking refuge in the unsurpassed Dharma of liberation, and in the supreme Saá¹…gha of Arhats.
I have heard that the tranquil Pratyekabuddhas understand the practice of dependent origination,
Their minds free from defilements, having eliminated afflictions, well-guarding the precepts, always pure.
Like the autumn sky without clouds, simple and austere, guarding themselves in the forests,
Now I yearn for their merits, sincerely respecting and following, giving rise to faith and joy.
Although I have doubts about them, their power moves me, forcing me to believe,
Who, upon hearing the pure and true practices of the noble ones, would not give rise to respectful and faithful thoughts?
I will now speak a little of the merits and wonderful practices of the Pratyekabuddhas,
I will only state the correct words without false speech,ğŸ”½The great elephant walks the path, the elephant cub follows,
Therefore I now open and reveal.
Question:

Why do pratyekabuddhas silently guard themselves, always enter the mind of equanimity, dwell in the secluded places of mountains, forests, and river banks, and have no verbal expressions due to the stillness of their mental activities, like the solitary behavior of a rhinoceros?
Why is it so?
Also asked:
What merits do pratyekabuddhas have?
Answer:
The ancient masters all say:ğŸ”½In the past, the Buddha was expounding the Dharma in the palace of the Thirty-three Heavens and was about to descend back to JambudvÄ«pa.

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, ordered ViÅ›vakarman to create three jeweled staircases for the Buddha to return to JambudvÄ«pa. These three staircases descended to the country of Saá¹ƒkÄ«ya.
At that time, the TathÄgata descended from the heavenly palace by the steps. Åšakra, BrahmÄ, and the other heavenly kings, together with their retinues, rained down flowers as offerings.

At that time, the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« Padma saw the Buddha coming down and immediately transformed herself into the appearance and demeanor of a wheel-turning sage king, with the seven treasures leading the way.
At that time, the people saw this and all gave rise to doubts, marveling at the unprecedented sight, and each said:
Is there anyone whose spiritual powers surpass those of the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«?

At that time, the World-Honored One saw that the assembly was deeply amazed at the three steps, and also saw that the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« Padma had manifested this spiritual transformation, causing them to yearn for it. In order to increase their faith, he then said to the assembly:
There are pratyekabuddhas whose spiritual powers surpass those of the bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«.
How is it called superior?
When the Buddha has not yet appeared in the world, they appear in the world to bring benefit to sentient beings.
Showing their physical appearance, they manifest hunger and thirst, accepting clothing and food as a field of merit.
Adorning the practice of the Dharma, pure and tranquil, taming and detaching from desires, causing sentient beings who see them to forever cease evil thoughts and abandon weapons.
Like a rhinoceros, they practice alone.
It is heard from various teachers that this matter was heard.
What matter was heard?

I once heard that during the time of Buddha Kasyapa, a person left home life and practiced pure conduct for ten thousand years, upholding the true precepts, cultivating patience, and always diligently practicing.
Because of his practice, many monks came to befriend him.
At that time, the monks all said:
You should teach us.
Because of the teaching, the minds of these monks all became joyful.
Because of the crowd's noise, he was unable to see the truth. At the time of his death, he thought:
I saw the Dharma spoken by the one with ten powers, subtle and profound, difficult to hear.
However, although I heard it, due to my indulgence, I did not attain the fruit of the path.

Although I purely upheld the precepts and was able to practice patience, because of teaching and transforming many people and being distracted, I invaded and destroyed my concentrated mind, like frost and hail harming good seedlings. For this reason, I did not attain the fruit of the path.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
I am now drowning in the three existences, in the midst of many evil afflictions,
Just like an old and emaciated elephant sinking in deep mud.
Like that pratyekabuddha, dwelling alone in the forest,
Like a rhinoceros with a single horn, far from the assembly of followers,
Avoiding a raging fire, one should practice alone,
Far from the hustle and bustle.
I wish to always stay far away from the hustle and bustle of the assembly.
Having made this vow, he ended his life and was reborn in the heavens, receiving heavenly bliss.
When his merit was exhausted and his life ended, he was reborn in the womb of the chief consort of King Brahmadatta in the city of Varanasi in the country of Kashi.
When he entered the womb, the body of the consort was like a clear pond with soft flowers.
At that time, the consort, knowing she was pregnant, spoke to the king in verse:
Since I became pregnant, I have been joyful and generous,
This must be the will of the child, and I should pardon those who have committed offenses.
When the king heard this, he was delighted and immediately pardoned the people of the world.
She also spoke to the king, saying:
You should also give generously on a large scale.
When the king heard this, he was even more delighted and immediately opened the treasury,
Providing for the poor people, none of whom were not fully satisfied.
At that time, when the consort gave birth to the prince, he was upright and extraordinary, like a full moon. At the age of eight, he was intelligent and kind.
When his father passed away, the people loved him as much as a full moon.
At that time, there was a chief minister named Vacana. Vacana the chief minister immediately established the prince to succeed to the throne.
Although he was young, by the power of his original vow he did not commit any evil, and his nature was virtuous, with deep compassion for all beings.

Although dwelling in the royal palace, he aspired for solitude; although dwelling in a flower hall, he was like in a charnel ground; although dwelling in commotion, he cultivated meditation, detested birth and death, weighed its faults, cultivated the mind with the Way, and abandoned royal affairs.
The ministers remonstrated, saying:
Today, the great king exclusively practices the Way and does not attend to state affairs.
If it is like this, various evils will certainly arise and ruin the king's moral influence.
It is like crossing the ocean. If there is no boatman, one will certainly be ruined by various difficulties.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
The king inherits his ancestors' succession, and obtains the land according to the Dharma,
He only tends to the myriad people, and does not wish to abandon the country.
If the king rules with the right Dharma, and there are no faults among the virtuous,
The lord of men should know that protecting the country with merit is supreme.
At that time, having heard these words, the king sighed in thought and replied in verse:
If I do not govern the country, my country will surely perish;
With my power, I can protect the country, and border evils dare not invade.
If I govern the country, the affairs of the king will defile my mind,
If there are those who commit crimes, they must be punished with harm,
I will say to imprison them, to cut off their hands and feet,
They should be sentenced to death, their eyes should be gouged out.
In this defiled and evil world, there must be capital punishment,
If one carries out capital punishment, they are a caá¹‡á¸Äla.
Then the king told his trusted ministers:
Listen now, what I eat is no more than one meal, what I wear is no more than one set of clothes, and the place where I sit and lie down is just enough to accommodate my body.
Considering this, why do I need to seek much and be insatiable?
The reason why the king's position is called honorable is because his orders must be carried out and all will respectfully obey. Only in this matter is he different from the common people.
He also told the prime minister:
The king's most important matter is this one thing, which I now entrust to you.
You should now fear the afterlife, rule the country with right Dharma, and levy taxes according to the old, without violating the usual limits.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Although I was born in the royal palace, inheriting the legacy of my ancestors,
I have never learned about punishing and beating.
Because I am now afraid, I cannot commit such acts.
You should not imitate me now, but should nurture the people.
The people of the world are all foolish and ignorant, each committing offenses,
And within the crimes they have committed, they give rise to fear.
You should use the correct Dharma to nurture and provide fearlessness,
And rely on the correct Dharma to guide the people.
When the king had spoken this verse, he then entrusted the country to this great minister.

After this great minister had obtained the country, for two years he was unrestrained and did not care for the people, indulging his desires and doing all kinds of wrong. Gradually, as time passed and his position of honor became more secure, he became arrogant and did many unlawful things, like a raging river that destroys much. He seized the wealth of the rich in the city.
At that time, the people in the city all admonished him, saying:
Do not do such things!
Hearing others' loyal words, he became even more angry, frowned, and said:
How dare you speak such words?
The people were afraid and did not dare to respond to the king.

For this reason, his conduct became increasingly unrighteous day by day, like a fire getting more and more intense when fed dry firewood. His licentiousness, violence, and chaos led him to commit heinous acts, even raping the king's beloved wife.
When the king's wife saw this, she was distressed and on the verge of tears. She went to inform the king.
With a fierce and angry mind, her lips trembling, her words incoherent like a child's, she told the king the details of the matter.
When the king heard this, he immediately summoned him and said:
You are still able to endure and commit such an offense even with my queen, let alone the rest of the people.
The king then admonished him:
From now on, do not act like this again.

When the prime minister saw that the king disliked him and the people were fed up with him, he immediately abandoned the country and fled to another land. He took the king of that country and his army and returned to his own country to attack and conquer it.
At that time, the old ministers and prime ministers of the country led troops to resist and defeat his army, capturing him alive and bringing him back.
The old ministers and prime ministers again said to the king:
That man has insulted and defamed the king.
They then took the minister to the king.
At that time, the king saw that his countenance had changed and he had an expression of shame and fear.
The king said:
How strange! Birth and death!
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The mind covered by foolishness does not realize the great suffering that will come later,
For the sake of a small amount of pleasure, one now suffers this shame and disgrace.
It is like a very good dish, with color and fragrance complete,
But mixed with poisonous medicine in it, a foolish person does not examine it,
Greedy for the taste, they take it and eat it, and when it is digested, it becomes harmful.
The king told the ministers and prime ministers:
Although his offense is extremely grave, I do not wish to harm him.
He then spoke another verse, saying:
All love their own lives, so quickly pardon that criminal.
I do not see anyone who harms the lives of others and yet attains peace and happiness.
For those with deep and grave crimes, one should give rise to a compassionate mind.
They themselves invite harm and blame, so one should give rise to pity and sympathy.
If one harms their lives, one will destroy the Dharma that one holds dear.
The old ministers then said to the king:
Although we now disobey the king's decree, we will definitely harm them and never let them go.
They then drew their swords in front of the king and beheaded them.

Seeing them killed, the king became disgusted. Seeing the past realms, the mind of forbearance he cultivated suddenly opened up, and he realized the path of pratyekabuddhahood, like when an utpala flower blooms.
He rose up into the sky, and all the ministers and aides looked up at him with palms joined.
The pratyekabuddhas who are weary of birth and death realize the Way in this way. The fruits of upholding precepts that I have now attained are like this.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
Although I wear necklaces, my mind cultivates pure brahmacarya.
Controlling the body and taming the faculties, always tranquil and simple.
To all people, I abandon weapons and sticks,
Cultivating the practice of solitude, like a rhinoceros with one horn.

After speaking this verse, his beard and hair fell out by themselves. At that time, the god of the Pure Abode presented him with a kÄá¹£Äya robe, and he immediately flew through the air to the Himalayas.
At that time, there was a pratyekabuddha in the mountain who asked him, saying:
You were in the position of a king, what things did you detest that you realized this trace of the Way?
He then spoke the above verse to answer him.
Therefore, the TathÄgata, for those who are unable to practice patience, expounds the causes and conditions of patience.
Because of craving and intimacy with busyness, he expounds the causes and conditions of not being intimate.
In order to make people understand the merits of pratyekabuddhas, the causes and conditions of pratyekabuddhas are explained.
The Buddha explained the causes and conditions of pratyekabuddhas in the Hall of Good Dharma for the sake of the devas.
The Buddha, in the Heaven of the Thirty-three, explained this matter in order to cause the devas to give rise to disgust and loathing.
The pratyekabuddha Vasiá¹£á¹­ha explained in VaiÅ›ÄlÄ« how to abandon the body and enter nirvÄá¹‡a. Now there is a stÅ«pa named UdÄyÄ«.
Upholding the precepts and not violating the practice, the wise ones attain liberation,
Not learning from others, not harming others, the solitary practice is like a rhinoceros.
I have heard this said by the masters.

At the time of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha, there was a bhiká¹£u who practiced pure conduct for ten thousand years, attained forbearance through sitting meditation, cultivated and upheld the precepts, stayed away from busyness, and was fully endowed with the practices of dhÅ«ta.
After his life ended, he was reborn in the heavens and experienced the pleasures of the five desires in the heavenly palace.
After the lifespan in the heavens was exhausted, he was reborn in the womb of the wife of the prime minister of the city of Vá¹›ji, Devadatta.
At that time, the wife spoke a verse to her husband:
I am now pregnant, and my mind is very joyful. It must be a person with blessings,
Coming to be my child.
For this reason, he always gave rise to compassion for all.
Moreover, I have now ceased from indulgent thoughts and have no more desires. It is like the MahÄmÄndÄrava mountain in the ocean that can cut off the waves. Now my desire to cease is also like this.
I now fear false speech and always think of truthful speech. Moreover, it is like a virtuous person who fears mistakes. Now my careful fear is also like this.

I now see alcohol as if beholding poison, and fear other people's possessions as if fearing a mass of fire. In this way, all these evils I now completely abandon, all due to the blessed child in my womb.
Since desire has been removed, what do you use for happiness?
At that time, the prime minister said to his wife:
Now, I will allow you to practice the five precepts as you wish.
At that time, the wife practiced many good deeds, and after ten months, she gave birth to a son named SÅ«ma.

Gradually growing up, he became well-versed in all scriptures, treatises, and the sixty-four arts. He was upright and extremely handsome, like a full moon, and was able to fulfill his parents' wishes.
Eventually, he reached adulthood. The prime minister requested the king:
I am now old and will prepare for the afterlife by practicing merit.
At that time, the king replied:
I cannot now obstruct your practice of merit.
You may have your son SÅ«ma take your place to serve me, and you may practice goodness as you wish.
The prime minister was delighted. The king appointed SÅ«ma as the prime minister, and bestowed upon him rewards and honors twice as great as his father's.
The people loved and respected him, just as they had in the past with the great minister Gopa, and he was able to arouse the love and respect of all women.
At that time, the king's wife loved SÅ«ma and said to him:
If you can now fulfill my wish, you can make the entire country and the king follow you.
And you will not get a bad reputation, and your instructions will be no different from the king's.
At that time, SÅ«ma held his resolve firmly and was not timid. He replied in verse:
Please listen to what I say, and do not see it as blameworthy.
When I heard these words, it was like being soaked into the ground.
It is like a weak horse, when it is exhausted, being ridden into the battlefield, unable to move forward.
When I see another's wife, my feelings are unattached, my mind is not open, like a lotus flower at night.
Whatever is respected, is no different from my mother;
How much more so for a human being, who is my superior.
I firmly hold my mind and respect my superior. I am his minister and son, and should not commit treason.
Moreover, when my desires arise, when I see another's wife, I naturally restrain myself.
When the floodwaters rise, there are many waves surging;
I am like the autumn waters, naturally pure and clear.
At that time, the queen thought to herself:ğŸ”½If he cuts off my intimate feelings,
I will certainly slander him.
She then said to the king:
The prime minister Suma has unreasonable intentions and wants to violate and insult me.
At that time, the king was confused and doubtful, wondering if it was true or not.
Then Suma went to the garden and saw two oxen plowing with yokes on their necks, extremely tired and suffering. He felt disgusted.
At that time, the king, deluded by the slanderous words of the queen, immediately sent someone to kill Somas.
At that time, Somas was like a horse shot by an arrow piercing to the bone. He immediately thought to himself:

When a person is in a position of honor, all the desirable forms come before him, like a meal mixed with poison that is extremely fragrant and delicious. When the desire to eat is about to be satisfied, the body then decays.
It is like a person greedy for the five desires, whose taste is extremely meager.
It is like a golden house being burned by fire. A person greedy for its color enters it and is harmed. When life is about to end, the mind and thoughts are disturbed.
He then comforted himself and thought to himself:
I uphold pure precepts without any violation.
As for my upholding of precepts, I know it is like the love of a yak for its tail.
I guard the precepts as if a poor person has obtained a treasure buried in the ground and diligently guards it.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
The rough, harsh, and dangerous path, I have already crossed it,
I am in a perilous situation, yet I protect the precepts and do not abandon them,
Just like the great ocean's tides, which do not miss their appointed time,
Now I guard and uphold the precepts, and the matter is also like this.
Having spoken this verse, at that time the devas and all the good spirits saw this prime minister's vow like this and all gave rise to joy.
Then the evil ghosts immediately possessed the queen. The queen became crazed and, possessed by the ghosts, spoke a verse in front of the king:
I now destroy myself; I should die with my body.
He is a pure and good person; one should not inflict harm on him.
I am foolish and ignorant; with my mouth I blow on Mount Sumeru,
But I cannot make it move.
He truly has no impure conduct; I falsely slander him like this.

At that time, the prime minister, contemplating disgust in the garden, attained pratyekabuddhahood, rose into the sky, his beard and hair fell out by themselves, and the gods of the Pure Abode presented him with a kaá¹£Äya robe.
At that time, the people exhorted him, saying:
Please do not abandon us and ascend to the heavens.
Then the pratyekabuddha spoke the above verse in reply to the people.
He flew to the Himalayas and saw the pratyekabuddhas, also explaining the above matter in detail.
The tides do not go beyond the limit, the yak dies guarding its tail,
Like the moon's nature is naturally cold, it cannot be changed to be hot.
One who subdues the faculties, guards the precepts likewise,
This is called the solitary practice, like the rhinoceros horn, without a second.
The great teachers of the past, passed on the teachings to each other,
I have heard from the superior ones of the past, now I wish to reveal and explain it.

In the past, there was a pratyekabuddha named CandrÄbha. He planted various roots of goodness and cultivated precepts and practices under the BhagavÄn KÄÅ›yapa Buddha. He always observed with wisdom that all the aggregates were impermanent. He did not attain the fruit of the path of Å›ramaá¹‡as under that Buddha.
When his life ended there, he was immediately reborn in the heavens, and due to the power of his past goodness, he experienced the bliss of the heavens.
When the lifespan of the heavens ended, he descended and was reborn in the home of a great elder in CampÄ, India.
From his early years, he was always upright and cultivated his body by relying on precepts and prohibitions.

Observing his good conduct, he surpassed the elders. He was also not impetuous, had no anger or resentment, and distributed his wealth to the poor and needy. He shared according to the abundance of the family, and adorned himself with the necklace of precepts.
When his father passed away, he governed the family in accordance with the Dharma.
The people of that city saw his loyalty and sincerity, and deeply gave rise to respect and faith, regarding him as a teacher.
He was in the prime of youth, with a handsome appearance. All the young women who saw him were infatuated with him. The merchants and traders all came to rely on him because of his trustworthiness.
At that time, there were merchants from the north who rode good horses to the country of CampÄ. The king of the country of CampÄ took all their horses.
The king was violent and tyrannical, not following the right Dharma. The king thought to himself:
Now that I have taken so many of their horses, how can I get them without paying the price?
He then gathered with his flatterers to discuss this matter. The flatterers said to the king:
If we pay the price, our treasury will be emptied.
The king then replied:
If I do not pay the price now, my bad reputation will spread throughout the world. All the people of the country will hate me, and trade with merchants from the four directions will be cut off.
The flatterers said again:
The plan for the king does not require money to obtain the horse, and it can also prevent the king's bad reputation from spreading and the people from suffering.
Now in the king's country, there is the minister Candraprabha, who is trusted by all the people.
If he comes to ask, the king should simply say:
'I sent Candraprabha to deliver the gold to you.'
At that time, the merchant had ten thousand horses, and each horse was worth ten thousand gold coins.
If the king just says 'Minister Candraprabha will pay the price,' the people in the country will certainly give rise to doubt, either suspecting the king or suspecting Candraprabha.
The king's bad reputation will not necessarily be exposed, and he will also not be disliked by the people.
The merchants came to the king and said:
Return the price of our horses, we want to go home.
The king then replied:ğŸ”½Didn't I previously have Candraprabha repay your price?
How can I give you the price again?
The merchants replied to the king, saying:
This CandrÄpÄ«á¸a has indeed not given us the price of the horse so far.
But he is loyal and trustworthy, and would rather give up his life than speak falsely and give us the price.
Then they spoke a verse, saying:
If the moon rains fire, and the sun rains cold water,
If sand is pressed to obtain oil, and water is drilled to obtain butter,
If a lotus grows in fire, then we would have CandrÄpÄ«á¸a
Speak coarse and false words, but this is never possible.
The merchants further said to the king,
God among men!
Even if CandrÄpÄ«á¸a really did as the king ordered and gave us the price, we would never resent it.
Then the king summoned CandrÄpÄ«á¸a and said to him,
Did you not say in front of me before that I gave you gold to repay a merchant?
The king then moved his eyes to make a strange sign, saying, If you do not comply with me, I will definitely kill you.
At that time, the minister Candraprabha privately thought to himself:ğŸ”½Should I follow the truth today?
Or should I follow the king's words?
He further contemplated:
Which is better to uphold, the Dharma body or this body?
He then decided:
I would rather abandon this body than abandon the precepts and Dharma body.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
I now contemplate within these two bodies,
Which one should I abandon?
I further observe carefully, it is better to discard this lowly and defiled form, but never abandon the precepts and rules;
If I were to abandon the Dharma body, my evil reputation would spread.
I am in the hands of those who practice many good deeds, and I am held by them;
If I do evil, I myself will not be happy or joyful,
The fire of remorse will arise in the mind, abandoning this defiled body,
One will then go to hell.
If one destroys the precepts oneself, one will never attain peace and happiness.
But for the sake of the happiness of one body, one will harm countless bodies;
If one protects the precepts, one will have peace and happiness for countless bodies.
Protecting the Dharma body, not allowing it to be destroyed,
For the sake of benefiting the true Dharma, one should abandon false speech.
The minister Candraprabha then said to the king:
May the king show mercy and not be angry with me. I truly do not remember seeing the king give him a reward.
At that time, the king became greatly angry and said, drawing his sword:
How is it that you do not see?
The minister Candraprabha then settled his mind and thought like this:
It is better to die for the sake of the holy Dharma, than to live foolishly;
In all existences, who is there who does not die?
If I die now, it is for the sake of the Dharma, and I will lose my life for the Dharma.
I am certain to be reborn in the heavens. Why should I be afraid?
He then replied to the king:
Even if the king were to cut up my body now and crush it into sesame seeds, I would never give up the precepts I have received.
Now that I abide in the path of sages and saints, if I were to speak falsely with this tongue, it would not be proper for me.
If I were now to speak falsely for the sake of the king, and later fall into hell, whom could I rely on?
The king was then ashamed and his anger doubled. He glared at him with eyes like a blazing fire.
At that time, CandrÄpÄ«á¸a's mind was filled with joy:
Now is the time for me to give rise to concentration. Now is the time for me to uphold the Dharma. Where else would I seek to hear the Dharma?
Today this is the Dharma being spoken for me.
Now I would give up my life for the Dharma. Now the king is a true great friend to me.

Thinking this, the Dharma immediately opened up and he attained pratyekabuddhahood. He then rose into the sky, causing those who had broken the precepts to see this and give rise to shame and remorse. For those cultivating goodness, it increased their faith and practice. For those speaking the truth, it manifested the true fruits of their actions.
In the sky, his beard and hair fell out by themselves, and the gods of the Pure Abode offered him Dharma robes.
He flew to Fragrant Mountain and gathered with the pratyekabuddhas in one place, speaking the verse as above.
